title: What is leukemia? - Danilo Allegra and Dania Puggioni

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why leukemia is the most common childhood cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Leukemia affects children more than any other type of cancer because it is caused by many DNA modifications.

options.label: B
options.text: Leukemia affects children more than any other type of cancer because it is caused by just one or two DNA modifications.

options.label: C
options.text: Leukemia affects children more than any other type of cancer because it is caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

options.label: D
options.text: Leukemia affects children more than any other type of cancer because it is caused by a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is a stem cell?

options.label: A
options.text: A fully developed cell that has lost its original function.

options.label: B
options.text: An undeveloped cell that has great potential.

options.label: C
options.text: A cell that has undergone specialization and has a specific function.

options.label: D
options.text: A cell that has died and is no longer functional.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of white blood cells?

options.label: A
options.text: To carry oxygen from the lungs to all tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: To help stop bleeding by sticking to damaged blood vessels.

options.label: C
options.text: To patrol the body and destroy potentially harmful invaders.

options.label: D
options.text: To specialize into different types of cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of leukemic cells reproducing in the blood and the bone marrow?

options.label: A
options.text: The production of functional cells increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of functional cells impairs the immune system and increases the risk of infections.

options.label: C
options.text: The bone marrow is able to produce the required amount of functional cells.

multiple-choice.question: Why is chemotherapy used to treat leukemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a surgical procedure that can remove leukemic cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a combination of drugs that destroys quickly multiplying cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a natural process that the body can do on its own.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a way to prevent the disease from occurring.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of bone marrow transplants?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove leukemic cells from the body.

options.label: B
options.text: To replace the bone marrow with healthy stem cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the production of functional cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is antigen compatibility?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of the donor and recipient to have the same genetic makeup.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of the donor and recipient to have different genetic makeup.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of the donor and recipient to have the same blood type.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of the donor and recipient to have different blood types.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of having a large database of bone marrow donors?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more patients to be treated with chemotherapy.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for more patients to receive bone marrow transplants.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for more patients to be cured of the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for more patients to be treated with surgery.

multiple-choice.question: Why is leukemia a frightening disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a rare disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a common disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a serious disease that can affect the immune system and increase the risk of infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a disease that can be cured easily.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for hope in treating leukemia?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to cure the disease with surgery.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to cure the disease with chemotherapy.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to cure the disease with bone marrow transplants and a large database of donors.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to prevent the disease from occurring.

title: Stroke of insight - Jill Bolte Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor's stroke?

options.label: B
options.text: A blood vessel explosion in the left half of her brain

multiple-choice.question: What was Dr. Taylor's experience like during the stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: She felt a sense of disconnection from her brain chatter and experienced a sense of peace and euphoria.

options.label: B
options.text: She felt a sense of fear and anxiety.

options.label: C
options.text: She felt a sense of numbness and disorientation.

options.label: D
options.text: She felt a sense of confusion and disconnection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the right hemisphere of the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Processing information in the present moment and thinking in pictures.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to a more peaceful world, according to Dr. Taylor?

options.label: A
options.text: Choosing to run the deep inner peace circuitry of the right hemisphere.

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing on linear thinking and methodical processing.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing a more logical and analytical mind.

options.label: D
options.text: Cultivating feelings of fear and anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Dr. Taylor's stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: She suffered permanent brain damage and was left with cognitive impairments.

options.label: B
options.text: She made a full recovery and returned to her normal life.

options.label: C
options.text: She experienced a shift in her consciousness and a newfound appreciation for the power of the human brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term Dr. Taylor uses to describe the state of being disconnected from her brain chatter?
What was Dr. Taylor's job before her stroke?
What is the primary function of the left hemisphere of the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Processing information in the present moment and thinking in pictures.

multiple-choice.question: What was the size of the blood clot that was removed from Dr. Taylor's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of a golf ball

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take Dr. Taylor to fully recover from her stroke?
